 FISE (NI-0065) EXECUTIVE SUMMARY BORROWER AND The Republic of Nicaragua GUARANTOR: EXECUTING AGENCY: The Emergency Social Investment Fund [Fondo de Inversi6n Social de Emergencia] (FISE) AMOUNT AND SOURCE: IDB: US$40.0 million (FSO) Local counterpart funding: US$ 4.0 million Total: US$44.0 million FINANCIAL Amortization period: 40 years TERMS AND Commitment period: 2 years CONDITIONS: Disbursement period: 3 years Grace period: 10 years Interest rate: 1% during grace period and 2% for the remaining 30 years Inspection and supervision: 1% Credit fee: 0.5% of undisbursed balances OBJECTIVES: The purpose of this operation, which constitutes the third stage of the FISE program, is to continue the current operations of FISE II for the financing of small social infrastructure projects and the stepping up of basic sanitation projects. In addition, it is proposed (i) to intensify the search for new lines of complementary projects that meet existing basic needs to reinforce the strategy of fighting poverty; (ii) to support programs for making the projects sustainable; (iii) to increase the participation by civil society in undertakings for its own community development and in the modernization of government; and (iv) to target efforts on the more depressed areas, with special attention to the Atlantic Autonomous Region (RAA). DESCRIPTION: The program has the following components: (i) investments in projects for small-scale infrastructure, equipment and community promotion needed to support the delivery of basic services; (ii) institutional strengthening of FISE to continue sustaining the executing unit and improving its
 Executive Summary Page 2 of 4 internal efficiency, and (iii) a maintenance fund to keep the investments sustainable. ENVIRONMENTAL The Environment Committee, at its meeting of Septem- CLASSIFICATION: ber 1, 1994, classified this as a Category III operation. BENEFITS: This operation will contribute to alleviating poverty, promoting the formation of human capital, and satisfying the basic needs of the population. This operation will serve as a catalyst for the acquisition of resources from other international sources of finance. FISE has a tentative budget, for its three-year operations program (1995-1997), of US$104.2 million, to be obtained from the following sources: (i) US$50.0 million from the World Bank; (ii) US$9.7 million from the KfW; (iii) US$9.5 mil- lion from USAID, and (iv) US$40.0 million - 38% of the total - from the IDB. RISKS: Given the fiscal austerity and operating deficiencies of the public agencies, the risk of deterioration of the installations built with FISE resources is heightened by the lack of preventive maintenance of the infrastructural works built. A maintenance fund is established for this purpose and support to community programs is stressed. FISE's lack of institutional capacity to diversify the menu of new types of complementary projects that satisfy the unmet basic needs of the population, in accordance with social priorities, is a constraint on accomplishment of the program's basic objectives. The program provides for institutional strengthening by setting up a fund for studies under the Office of the Director for Promotion and the creation of a Coiuimunications Unit. The proximity of the elections could entail a risk in the allocation of resources in accordance with social priorities. The targeting scheme adopted by FISE, the timetable for provision of the resources, and the inventory of projects evaluated without financing will all help reduce the risk of the operation. THE BANK'S The Bank has worked out its strategy with the Govern- COUNTRY AND ment of Nicaragua with a view to reactivating the SECTOR STRATEGY: traditional production sectors, increasing foreign exchange receipts, reducing unemployment, and alle- viating poverty. In view of the prevalence of poverty in the country, it is recommended that the poverty alleviation strategy be comprehensive, and
 Executive Summary Page 3 of 4 address institutional, structural and policy aspects. This strategy emphasizes that FISE will remain the best vehicle to target poverty alleviation in the short run because of its institutional and technical capabilities and its systems, which are well-suited for transparent resource allocation. SPECIAL A. Conditions precedent to submission to the Board CONTRACTUAL CONDITIONS: The executive decree extending the duration of FISE shall have been presented (fulfilled). B. Conditions precedent to the first aisbursement. Before the first disbursement from the loan financ- ing, the borrower shall, through the executing agency, present evidence satisfactory to the Bank: (i) of having signed the agreement transferring the resources in the form of a grant, includ- ing the commitment of the local contribution to the maintenance fund; (ii) that the local counterpart contribution has been made; (iii) that the interinstitutional agreements with the Ministry of Education (MED) and the Ministry of Health (MINSA), approved by the Bank, have been signed; (iv) that the Operating Regulations approved by the Bank have been implemented for execution of the program. C. Other special conditions. The borrower shall, through the executing agency, present to the Bank's satisfaction: (i) evidence of having signed, within 90 days of issuance of the regulations implementing the law on "Permits and Evaluation of Environ- mental Impact", the framework interinsti- tutional coordination agreement with the Ministry of the Environment and Natural Resources (MARENA); (ii) within 90 days of the entry into force of the contract, the basic list of indicators for parallel monitoring;

Introduction 1.1 Since the project described herein is a continuation of operation 729/OC, which the Bank recently approved for the FISE and is still in execution, this document is presented in shortened form. The present operation focuses on evaluation of the gains made by the program in execution, and contains a description of the new pro- gram, with the adjustments required to make it more efficient. Economic situation and the stabilization and structural adjustment program 1.2 The economy of Nicaragua has undergone profound changes after a decade of deep stagnation. The stabilization and structural adjustment program launched in 1990 has made important gains: (i) inflation dropped to 20% in 1993 from more than 7,000% in 1990; (ii) the size of the government has been reduced with the privatization of 253 government enterprises, the release of 60,000 men from the army and the removal of 10,000 public posts from the central government's payroll, and (iii) structural reforms have been made in the trade and finance sectors with the establishment of legal frameworks for the establishment of private banking and the Superintendency of Banks. In addition, the government has carried out a variety of programs targeted at low-income groups, which have generated about 90,000 jobs under temporary programs. At present the Government of Nicaragua is beginning a modernization of the State under a public sector reform program. 1.3 Despite these gains, it has not been possible to sustain economic development. With the lack of economic growth, together with high growth of the population, unemployment has risen to 21.8%, which has added to the poverty in the country. 1.4 In 1993 GDP fell 0.9%. Agriculture was affected by the decline of international prices, and production fell off in almost all manu- facturing subsectors. A modest recovery of economic growth is expected in 1994, estimated at 2% of GDP and generated by a recov- ery of animal production, fishing and plant production. C. The social framework 1.5 The low welfare level of the Nicaraguan population is reflected in substandard basic services and a high incidence of poverty. The per capita GDP is the lowest in Latin America after Haiti and Guyana. The indicators of health, nutrition and education are among the lowest in the region. Some 28% of the children suffer
 - 2 - from some form of malnutrition. Infant mortality stands at 72 per 1,000 live births, caused mainly by preventable diseases (diarrhea), which are associated with a shortage of drinking water and sanitation. Maternal mortality is 159 per 100,000 live births - the highest in Central America. The social problems are aggravated by a population growth rate of 3.3% a year. 1.6 The school drop-out and repeater rates are the highest in the region. Only 22% of the children who enter first grade complete their primary schooling. Some 23% of the population is illiterate, and this proportion is higher among the extremely poor, who are 51% illiterate. In the urban population the level of illiteracy is higher among women than among men. 1.7 About 46% of the country's population has no safe drinking water supply, and in the countryside the figure is only 20%. It is estimated that 82% of the national population is affected by prob- lems of sewage and human waste disposal. 1.8 In addition to the country's very poor performance on leading social indicators, there are constraints on expenditures for social purposes and institutional limitations that reduce managerial capa- bilities. The social ministries are in critical need of institu- tional reform if a social program is to be designed that can check the drastic decline in services that are essential for the develop- ment of human capital. D. The government's social strate&y 1.9 The terms of a social strategy of the Government of Nicaragua for the short run were formulated in October 1992. A Social Agenda for 1993-1996 sets out the basic principles of the social function. The proposal sets the following purposes: (i) to provide for the poorest and most vulnerable population; (ii) to make basic services more efficient and effective; and (iii) to support the production sectors that are excluded from the formal market. The strategic criteria for implementation of the Social Agenda are: (i) adminis- trative and financial decentralization, (ii) promotion of the community and its participation in the identification of needs, (iii) coordination between the central government and the local governments, (iv) the targeting of resources, and (v) rehabilita- tion of existing and construction of new physical capacity in the primary care and education facilities and child-care centers. 1.10 Within the framework established by the government's Social Agenda for 1993-1996, FISE has the task of continuing to mitigate the critical situation evidenced by the country's social indicators after a decade of war. FISE operates by financing small-scale projects to generate employment in the poorer areas by rehabili- tating social infrastructures in education and health and extending the network of basic water and sanitary sewerage services in rural and marginal urban areas. These operations respond to the basic
 3- needs of the populations earning the lowest incomes and thereby contribute to modernization of the State. 1.11 The World Bank is working with the Government of Nicaragua to chart a medium- and long-term policy of support for the social strategy. In addition, (i) in the education sector the World Bank and USAID are carrying forward the program for decentralization and strength- ening of basic education; (ii) in the health sector the IDB, in coordination with other multilateral and bilateral agencies, is supporting the reform of the sector, and (iii) in the sanitation sector the IDB, through the program for rehabilitation of drinking water supply and sewerage systems, is supporting rehabilitation of those systems in Managua and several cities elsewhere in the coun- try. In addition, institutional strengthening, including rate studies, is being provided. E. The Bank's strategy 1.12 The Bank has worked out its strategy with the Government of Nica- ragua for reactivation of the traditional production sectors, increasing foreign exchange receipts, reducing unemployment, and alleviating poverty. Given the prevalence of poverty in Nicaragua, it is recommended that the poverty alleviation strategy be compre- hensive, and address institutional, structural and policy aspects. This strategy emphasizes that FISE will remain the best vehicle to target poverty alleviation in the short run because of its institu- tional and technical capabilities and its systems, which are well- suited for transparent resource allocation. F. The Emergency Social Investment Fund 1. Background 1.13 FISE was established in 1990 as a temporary autonomous institution. It was to exist until 1995 as an instrument of social compensation to protect the living standards of disadvantaged population groups from the effects of structural adjustment measures. Since despite major success in stabilizing the economy it has not been possible to restart economic growth and the social indicators remain at critical levels, the Government of Nicaragua has issued an execu- tive decree extending FISE's existence to 1997. 1.14 The Bank and other bilateral and multilateral organizations and agencies, including the World Bank, USAID, CIDA, UNDP, SCD, KfW, and IDA, have supported the institution's establishment and opera- tions. The Bank's contribution was of key importance in guaran- teeing the institution's sustainability and efficiency in the allocation of its resources to the other donors. FISE has acquired resources totaling US$120 million, of which US$107 million are for investments in subprojects, and US$9 million for its institutional strengthening of itself and that of some line ministries. The balance is resources to cover the administration agreements and

Accomplishments 1.23 The accomplishments of the program have been examined in terms of its institutional efficiency, the coverage of its projects, the quality of its works, and the magnitude of FISE's presence in the social sector. a. Institutional efficiency 1.24 FISE has attained quite a satisfactory level of institutional success. According to its performance indicators, in the third quarter of 1994 it had made substantial progress towards its targets (see paragraph 1.16 and Annex I-1). Its operating costs are quite reasonable, as noted in paragraph 1.17. The mid-term
 -6- report of the World Bank mission states that FISE's institutional success is owed primarily to (i) the priority it has been given at high policy-making levels of the government, (ii) the contractual facilities (market.-competitive remuneration for its personnel and flexible procedures for the award and contracting of works) allowed by its charter law, and (iii) the professional quality of its staff. It is also worth noting that the eligibility and selection criteria and evaluation methodologies have been rigorously applied. 1.25 Since its inception, FISE has made great efforts to target its resources to respond to the basic needs of the poorest. To program the distribution of its resources, the institution has designed a geographical targeting strategy in which it allocates them to the municipal level. This strategy has been based on a per capita distribution adjusted by poverty indicators (including access to drinking water, malnutrition, and displaced population), so that the country's poorest municipalities benefit proportionally the most from the project financing. FISE has constructed a poverty map that constitutes a contribution to the strategy for the social sector. Under the proposed operation this poverty map would be updated. b. Project coverage 1.26 Although the institution was established only a short time ago, its effects are already being reflected in benefits to the target population. The program has covered all 143 existing municipal- ities and is estimated to have generated 12,780 employment years. The works contracted for have benefitted 3,321,731 persons. Based on the low-income threshold agreed upon between the government and the Bank, 100% of the target population is below the poverty line (US$960.00 per capita/year). The real cumulative investment per beneficiary in the categories of extreme, severe and moderate pov- erty is US$24.20, US$17.40 and US$14.50, respectively. The opera- tion meets the poverty reduction criterion specified in the report on the Eighth General Increase of the Bank, since low-income groups account for 50 percent of the country's population, making for a coefficienc of greater than 2 in terms of low-income beneficiaries. 1.27 Up to September 1994, FISE had provided for 15% of the primary schools in the country (more than 4,000 schools, most of them in a deteriorating state) by repairing or rehabilitating 602 primary school and preschool buildings and providing 249,129 desks. It has improved the educational conditions of 171,505 children for whose education even the minimum requirements were not present before the project. Direct benefits have been received by 66% of the rural and 34% of the urban schools either in buildings or equipment. In addition, FISE has carried out 55 secondary-school projects, which have benefitted 36,519 students. 1.28 FISE has also executed 148 health post projects, which are benefit- ing 550,240 families, most of them in the countryside. The works

FISE has developed community participation projects in the sectors of education, health and basic sanitation, including basic preventive health projects. The lessons learned from these experiences have been positive, for the more the community participates in the identification of its own needs, the better the supervision and upkeep of the works. 1.31 The impact on women is considerable. Objectives 2.1 The main objective of the program is to continue supporting Nicara- gua in the alleviation and reduction of poverty by financing proj- ects for small-scale works in the sectors of health, education and basic sanitation. At this new stage, sanitation operations would be stepped up and, in addition to the actions already in progress under FISE II, the program would (i) intensify the search for new complementary lines of projects to satisfy existing basic needs by strengthening the strategy of fighting poverty, (ii) give support to programs to make the projects sustainable, (iii) step up the participation of civil society in its community development under- takings and in the modernization of the State, and (iv) target efforts at the most depressed areas, wich special attention to the RAA. JUSTIFICATION 5.1 The lack of census information on population and housing in Nicara- gua over the last 20 years and on agriculture over the last 30, has made it difficult to take policy decisions in government and the
 ANNEX II-2 Page 7 of 11 private sphere, which has prompted these sectors to make their own enumerations for purposes of both economic and social investments. 5.2 These isolated efforts to generate information have not only been expensive, but the information generated has proved an unreliable basis for making decisions, which has imposed severe constraints on the design of policies, projects and measures in the economic and social sectors. 5.3 One of the principal problems preventing INEC from carrying out a census is a lack of equipment for data processing, the printing of enumeration forms and materials for taking down data, and brief- cases and insignia for the field staff. 5.4 Priority will be given to training the INEC personnel, and particu- larly the staff who will be processing the census data. Also, to do the enumeration work satisfactorily, INEC will need equipment and vehicles to distribute the enumeration forms to all localities in the country and to enable the personnel to move about during the preparatory work and the enumeration itself. 5.5 There is important agricultural information that must be made available without waiting for the next census to provide it, which would not otherwise be possible until the end of the century. The last agricultural census was carried out in 1971, but all the information it produced was lost in the earthquake of 1977. Hence the data being worked with are those of 1963. This agricultural information is important for the programs being financed by the Bank in the sector, such as FOSEMAG (921/SF and 801/OC-NI), PNDR (927/SF-NI), and the national accounts component of the technical-cooperation operation for reform of the Central Bank (ATN/SF-3885-NI), and for other multilateral and bilateral agencies. 5.6 Hence financing to carry out the activities called for in this plan of operations is justified because if the government, through INEC, is to undertake an operation on the magnitude of the national cen- sus, the technical personnel that will carry out those activities will have to be strengthened and computer equipment provided to process the high volume of census information reliably and expedi- tiously so that it may be available before the next elections, to be held in 1996.

doc.abstracts: The Second Social Investment Fund Project will help the Government sustain its poverty alleviation efforts and maintain social cohesion during the economic adjustment period. Additionally, the project will help support the Government's decentralization strategy, strengthen the local contracting industry, broaden the menu of projects that the Energy Social Investment Fund finances, support the targeting of resources to more depressed areas, and help meet the special needs of the indigenous population. The project will have the following four components: (i) investment subprojects; (ii) institutional strengthening; (iii) a Living Standards Measurement Survey; and (iv) a maintenance fund.
